course_title: Principles of the International Tourism System

learning_outcomes.description: Explain the interrelated structure of the global tourism and events sector using a systems approach.
Justify the relevance of the tourism system for tourism and event businesses in the private sector.
Identify and explain the potential impact of external influences on the tourism system.
Evaluate the role of transport modes within the tourism system and its importance in developing an integrated visitor experience.

assessments.task_description:
Background 

Assessment Tasks 1, 2, and 3 are interconnected; your plans and feedback from each task will support the next. Therefore, choose a scenario that interests you, as per the criteria below, as your selection will affect all three tasks.

Scenario

You are in a management position at a privately owned company that manages tourist attraction(s) and/ or event(s). As a manager of this company, you are one of a number of people on the Executive Committee. Your company has been very successful over recent years, but you have some concerns that the Committee is starting to get a bit complacent and is losing sight of the bigger picture. You have been doing some part-time study, and you have been learning about tourism systems. Leiper's Tourism System (LTS) stood out to you as a good model to apply to one tourist attraction or event that your company manages.

Assessment overview 

Through your three (3) assessment tasks this semester, you will convince the Executive Committee of the benefits of applying LTS to your chosen tourist attraction or event. This is how the three tasks link together:

  1. You will draft a proposal to outline your ideas and reasoning of applying LTS to your attraction/event. You will receive feedback before presenting to the Executive Committee. 
  2. You will deliver a 5-minute pitch + 5 minutes questions and discussion to the Executive Committee, where you will justify why applying the LTS to your attraction/event is beneficial from a management perspective.
  3. As required by the Committee following your pitch, you will evaluate and report on the role of transport throughout your tourism system. 


Selecting a tourist attraction or event

When choosing a tourist attraction or event:

  • Your choice of one tourist attraction or event must be a small to medium enterprise (SME). NOTE: Mega events like the Olympics, and tourist attractions like Disneyland, are too big and are therefore not suitable.
  • The tourist attraction or event you choose needs to be real. It should be an attraction or event that you are familiar with and/or that you have visited.
  • Be mindful that the tourist to this chosen attraction/event must originate from a generating region where distance requires that the tourist spend at least one night at the destination. Moreover, the generating, transit and destination must be distinct regions.
  • Your research will ONLY be based on publicly available information. Do NOT contact the management company or the tourist attraction or event.
  • Each student must have a different tourist attraction or event. Therefore, the quicker you select and confirm your tourist attraction or event with your teaching team, the better chance you will have of getting your choice of attraction or event. An updated list will be managed by the teaching team and made available on Blackboard throughout the semester.  
  • The management company you are representing does not need to be real, but it can be the company that owns the tourist attraction or event.


Task description 

Your first task is to draft a proposal (recorded video of 2-3 minutes) that explains your ideas and reasoning for applying LTS to your chosen attraction or event. Your proposal should be clear, engaging, and convincing to your audience. Since the Executive Committee may not be familiar with LTS, your proposal must present the concept in simple and clear terms. You will submit this proposal using the AI Bongo Learn platform where you will receive feedback from AI and the teaching team before presenting to the committee. 

Purpose 

This assessment is designed to: 

• Develop skills in structuring and presenting your ideas clearly and effectively within a limited timeframe.

• Use feedback as learning to strengthen your pitch to the Executive Committee (Assessment 2).

Instructions 

Your proposal must include

• a brief description of the tourist attraction or event your company is managing;

• identification of one (1) target market and its generating region;

• a description of the transit region;

• a description of the destination region;

• only one (1) PowerPoint slide for your proposal. 

You will submit your proposal (recorded video) on the Bongo Learn tool accessed through Blackboard. On the platform, alongside your recording, you must attach your one slide PPT. To receive a mark for this assessment task, both the recording and the one-slide PPT must be submitted, as one will not be accepted in place of the other. Ensure you keep the submission receipt screenshot for your reference.

Other information 

Task format

[Bongo information]

Bongo Learn is a video-based learning and assessment platform that will help you practice your presentation skills and receive feedback on your performance. When you record your pitch using the platform, it will use AI to provide feedback on your performance based on the marking criteria of the assessment. To receive feedback from Bongo, log in through Blackboard, open Bongo, and click the Record button to begin your recording. You will also see an attachment icon, which you can use to upload your PowerPoint file.

In using Bongo Learn, you get repeated practice and immediate reflection opportunities, helping you improve your oral presentation skills. 

Further instructions will be provided in the class.

Use of artificial intelligence

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
Week 7 - Week 8

This is an in-class presentation/assessment, to be delivered during the tutorial you are enrolled in.
assessments.task_description:
Scenario

Now that you have received feedback on your proposed tourism system (Assessment Task 1), you are confident that applying Leiper's Tourism System (LTS) to your tourist attraction or event would be useful to ensure its longevity. You have approached the Chair of the Executive Committee for your company, and they have given you space on the agenda at the next Committee meeting to justify and discuss your ideas. 

Task description 

Your next task is to present a pitch to the Executive Committee, justifying why you believe applying LTS to your attraction or event is beneficial from a management perspective. You are allotted a total of 10-minutes in the meeting; 5-minutes should be dedicated to delivering your pitch, followed by 5-minutes for questions and discussions with the committee.

Purpose 

This assessment is designed to: 

• Apply theoretical knowledge (including LTS) to practice through a real-world tourist attraction or event. 

• Communicate complex ideas and justify your reasoning through persuasive communication.

Instructions

Prepare and deliver a 5-minute pitch to the Executive Committee. Your pitch must include: 

  • a description of your chosen tourist attraction or event; 
  • an image of your system and its functionality. This will be based on LTS, and it can be either computer-generated or hand-drawn.
  • a justification for why you believe applying LTS to your attraction or event is beneficial from a management perspective; and
  • a profile of one (1) existing or potential target market for your attraction or event.
  • THEN, based on your chosen target market, also identify and justify: 
  • the characteristics of an appropriate generating region, including why this information is relevant;
  • the characteristics of the transit region, including why this information is relevant;
  • the characteristics of the destination, including why this information is relevant; and
  • two (2) external influences that could impact your system, including the potential nature of their impact.

Present your pitch in a way that best showcases your ideas, using a format of your choice (e.g., handouts, poster illustrations, drawings, slide deck, etc). You are encouraged to be creative. The key is to choose a format that will help you to clearly and accurately demonstrate your deep disciplinary knowledge, precisely apply relevant theory, and integrate that knowledge to produce novel insights. Following your pitch, there will be a 5-minute question and discussion with the Executive Committee. You should be prepared to: 

  • Justify the relevance of Leiper’s tourism system for tourism and event businesses in the private sector;
  • Explain the elements of your tourism system to the committee; and
  • Explain the potential impact of external influences on the tourism system.


Other information 

Task format

  • This assessment will be conducted within class time as an oral presentation + Q&A.
  • Committee meeting recording: Please note that this assessment will be recorded as required by UQ’s Assessment Procedure. 
  • References are NOT required to be included in the pitch itself. 
  • Resources - Your research will ONLY be based on publicly available information. Do NOT contact the management company or the tourist attraction or event. 


How to prepare/tips 

  • Think about your presentation from the perspective of your audience (Executive Committee). These are managers from a range of areas (sales, human resources, finance, etc) who may not have any prior knowledge of Leiper's Tourism System.
  • Your presentation style is important. If you do not make your presentation engaging, it is unlikely that the Committee will listen to what you have to say. 


AI Statement

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Visual aid to the preseantation must be submitted via File Upload to Blackboard by 05:00 pm on the day of your presentation.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Scenario

The Executive Committee was impressed with your Tourism System Pitch (Assessment Task 2), but they would like you to provide more information about the transport aspect of your system. The Committee has requested that you submit a transport subsystem in the format of a project report of 1500-2000 words.

Assessment Task 3: Transport Subsystem Report

In your Tourism System Pitch, you described the transit region for the tourism system for your chosen tourist attraction or event. The Committee would like you to elaborate on this further to identify the role of transport throughout your tourism system (ie. not just in the transit region). 

Structure your report using the following sections:

  1. System overview (200-250 words): use the feedback from Assessments 1 and 2 to provide an improved brief description of your tourism system. Include an image of your (revised) tourism system based on the feedback from Assessments 1 and 2.
  2. Modes of transport:
  • identify each mode of transport and explain why each one is, or is not, relevant for your transport subsystem;
  • for each mode that is relevant to your transport subsystem, describe the relevant carrying unit(s); their motive power(s); and terminal(s);
  • include a diagram of your transport subsystem as it relates to your tourism system from Assessment 2

3. Transit route - an example:

  • identify one (1) transit route that you would encourage your target market to use to visit your attraction or event;
  • detail your chosen transit route from a visitor’s perspective;
  • detail your chosen transit route from a management perspective (ie. why you chose this route; and what planning is required 'behind the scenes' to make this a seamless transit route from the visitor's perspective).

4. Identify any emerging trends that could impact your transport subsystem. For each trend you identify, discuss the potential nature of its impact.

5. Justify why understanding the transport subsystem is relevant from the Committee's perspective. 

Note:

  • You will need to provide references. These may be from a combination of academic articles, industry reports and credible online websites. (NOTE: If you are uncertain about any potential sources/references, please check with the teaching team before writing your report.)
  • You will be prompted in your weekly tutorials to apply relevant theory to this assessment task so that you are building up your skills and knowledge progressively across the semester. We will also discuss this assessment task in more depth during class.

Formatting:

  • Line spacing: 1.5 lines
  • Font: Arial; Times New Roman; or Calibri
  • Font size: 12
  • Referencing: APA7

AI Statement

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
What is the International Tourism System?

Understanding how to create a tourist attraction or event is only part of a manager’s role. Managers also need to be able to see the attraction or event within the bigger picture – they need to understand the tourism system.

This week you will be introduced to systems thinking and the elements that make up the international tourism system.


Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: What is the International Tourism System? Understanding how to create a tourist attraction or event is only part of a manager’s role. Managers also need to be able to see the attraction or event within the bigger picture – they need to understand the tourism system. This week you will be introduced to systems thinking and the elements that make up the international tourism system.

learning_activities.topic:
LTS - tourist and generating region

Two of the key elements of the tourism system are the tourist and the generating region. As managers we need to understand our tourists – our target market. Importantly, we also need to understand where these tourists are coming from – their generating region. What does the generating region need to provide to enable its citizens to be tourists and why is this important for a tourism or event manager to know?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: LTS - tourist and generating region Two of the key elements of the tourism system are the tourist and the generating region. As managers we need to understand our tourists – our target market. Importantly, we also need to understand where these tourists are coming from – their generating region. What does the generating region need to provide to enable its citizens to be tourists and why is this important for a tourism or event manager to know?

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment 1 (Proposal video) - getting started

We will spend time getting to know each other. Then we will unpack and get started on Assessment 1.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Assessment 1 (Proposal video) - getting started We will spend time getting to know each other. Then we will unpack and get started on Assessment 1.

learning_activities.topic:
LTS - transit region

Knowing the target market for your attraction or event is a good start but how will they get from their generating region (home) to the attraction or event? What is the relevance of the geographical space between the generating regions and destination region? Why is this a consideration for the manager of the attraction or event?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: LTS - transit region Knowing the target market for your attraction or event is a good start but how will they get from their generating region (home) to the attraction or event? What is the relevance of the geographical space between the generating regions and destination region? Why is this a consideration for the manager of the attraction or event?

learning_activities.topic:
Transit region - more than modes of transport

The transit region is about much more than the types of transport that can be used. We will explore different ways a transit region can be used. Are some ways more sustainable than others? As managers, can we influence how transit regions are used?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_title: Transit region - more than modes of transport
learning_activities.topic_description: Transit region - more than modes of transport The transit region is about much more than the types of transport that can be used. We will explore different ways a transit region can be used. Are some ways more sustainable than others? As managers, can we influence how transit regions are used?

learning_activities.topic:
LTS - destination region

An attraction or event sits within a destination. But what do tourists expect of destinations? And what do managers of attractions and events need destinations to provide?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: LTS - destination region An attraction or event sits within a destination. But what do tourists expect of destinations? And what do managers of attractions and events need destinations to provide?

learning_activities.topic:
Relevance of TALC for a SME

Ensuring your attraction or event is in the right destination is critical for success. This week we explore some strategies that can help managers to choose the ‘right’ destination. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Relevance of TALC for a SME Ensuring your attraction or event is in the right destination is critical for success. This week we explore some strategies that can help managers to choose the ‘right’ destination.

learning_activities.topic:
LTS - external influences

Understanding the tourism system is important for creating memorable tourism experiences. However, there are external influences that can have positive or negative impacts on a tourism system. These external influences cannot be controlled by managers within the tourism system. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: LTS - external influences Understanding the tourism system is important for creating memorable tourism experiences. However, there are external influences that can have positive or negative impacts on a tourism system. These external influences cannot be controlled by managers within the tourism system.

learning_activities.topic:
My external influences

We need to do more than be aware of potential external influences. We need to know how to scan the external environments and how to respond when external influences impact our system.

Learning outcomes: L01, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: My external influences We need to do more than be aware of potential external influences. We need to know how to scan the external environments and how to respond when external influences impact our system.

learning_activities.topic:
Preparation for your tourism system presentation

After the in-semester break you will be presenting your Tourism System (Assessment 2) in class. This week we provide tips for completing Assessment 2.
learning_activities.topic_description: Preparation for your tourism system presentation After the in-semester break you will be presenting your Tourism System (Assessment 2) in class. This week we provide tips for completing Assessment 2.

learning_activities.topic:
Field trip

On this tutorial day, we leave the classroom to engage in some experiential learning about the transport sub-system. This is important learning for Assessment 3 (Transport Subsystem Report).

Learning outcomes: L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Field trip On this tutorial day, we leave the classroom to engage in some experiential learning about the transport sub-system. This is important learning for Assessment 3 ( Transport Subsystem Report ).

learning_activities.topic: In Semester Break
learning_activities.topic_description: In Semester Break

learning_activities.topic:
LTS - Systems and subsystems

So far this semester we have explored the tourism system. But systems are made up of subsystems. This week we consider the subsystems that are needed for the tourism system to function.

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: LTS - Systems and subsystems So far this semester we have explored the tourism system. But systems are made up of subsystems. This week we consider the subsystems that are needed for the tourism system to function.

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment 2 In-Class Presentation

This week you will be presenting to the Committee (Assessment 2). All students are part of the committee so the expectation is that all students attend to support their peers and to ask questions.

Learning outcomes: L02
learning_activities.topic_description: Assessment 2 In-Class Presentation This week you will be presenting to the Committee (Assessment 2). All students are part of the committee so the expectation is that all students attend to support their peers and to ask questions.

learning_activities.topic:
Transport - road

The most used mode of transport is road transport. But what does this look like for tourists? When and why would tourists choose road transport over other types of transport?

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Transport - road The most used mode of transport is road transport. But what does this look like for tourists? When and why would tourists choose road transport over other types of transport?

learning_activities.topic:
Assessment 2 In-Class Presentation Continued

This week you will be presenting to the Committee (Assessment 2). All students are part of the committee so the expectation is that all students attend and support their peers and to ask questions.

 

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Assessment 2 In-Class Presentation Continued This week you will be presenting to the Committee (Assessment 2). All students are part of the committee so the expectation is that all students attend and support their peers and to ask questions.

learning_activities.topic:
Transport - air

The type of transport that often comes to mind first for tourists is air transport. We explore how air transport has changed where and how people travel. 

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Transport - air The type of transport that often comes to mind first for tourists is air transport. We explore how air transport has changed where and how people travel.

learning_activities.topic:
Touring routes and Air Transport

Combined, road and air transport account for how many tourists travel. But how can we encourage sustainable use of these modes of transport? We consider touring routes as a means of enticing tourists to explore the transit region. We also unpack Assessment 3 (Transport Subsystem Report).

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Touring routes and Air Transport Combined, road and air transport account for how many tourists travel. But how can we encourage sustainable use of these modes of transport? We consider touring routes as a means of enticing tourists to explore the transit region. We also unpack Assessment 3 ( Transport Subsystem Report ).

learning_activities.topic:
Transport - rail

Rail transport has come a long way in recent years. This week we explore what this means for other modes of transport – could rail transport become more popular than air and road transport?

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Transport - rail Rail transport has come a long way in recent years. This week we explore what this means for other modes of transport – could rail transport become more popular than air and road transport?

learning_activities.topic:
The pros and cons of rail transport

How do the famous railways of the world ‘fit’ into the tourism system? Are they transit regions? Are they destinations? Why does it matter?

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: The pros and cons of rail transport
learning_activities.topic_description: The pros and cons of rail transport How do the famous railways of the world ‘fit’ into the tourism system? Are they transit regions? Are they destinations? Why does it matter?

learning_activities.topic:
Transport - water

Water transport is so much more than cruise tourism. We explore the many and varied types of water transport and consider how they contribute to the tourism system.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Transport - water Water transport is so much more than cruise tourism. We explore the many and varied types of water transport and consider how they contribute to the tourism system.

learning_activities.topic:
Cruise tourism

Cruise tourism is the fastest growing sector of tourism. Why is this happening and what does this mean for the tourism system? We will also discuss the implications of water transport for Assessment 3.

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Cruise tourism Cruise tourism is the fastest growing sector of tourism. Why is this happening and what does this mean for the tourism system? We will also discuss the implications of water transport for Assessment 3.

learning_activities.topic:
Emerging issues for transport

Let’s slow it all down. What is slow tourism and what modes of transport best support this emerging tourism trend? 

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: Emerging issues for transport Let’s slow it all down. What is slow tourism and what modes of transport best support this emerging tourism trend?

learning_activities.topic:
What transport options have we missed?

With the rise in micro mobility (e-bikes/ scooters) what does this mean for the transport subsystem of the tourism system?

Learning outcomes: L01, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: What transport options have we missed? With the rise in micro mobility (e-bikes/ scooters) what does this mean for the transport subsystem of the tourism system?

learning_activities.topic:
An integrated tourism system

Modes of transport do not work in isolation. They need to be part of an integrated subsystem. This week we consolidate the semester’s learning by highlighting the importance of an integrated transport subsystem within a tourism system.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: An integrated tourism system Modes of transport do not work in isolation. They need to be part of an integrated subsystem. This week we consolidate the semester’s learning by highlighting the importance of an integrated transport subsystem within a tourism system.

learning_activities.topic:
Consultations for Assessment 3

Consultation for Assessment 3. Details of the nature of this session will be announced via Blackboard throughout the semester.
learning_activities.topic_description: Consultations for Assessment 3 Consultation for Assessment 3. Details of the nature of this session will be announced via Blackboard throughout the semester.
